text: It's ridiculous. I would say that by the time we are done recording this podcast, I'll have, I don't know. I mean, it could be anywhere from 30 to 50 pitches in my inbox. It comes all day. Now, to be clear, most of that is garbage in the real garbagey sense, right. It's a lot of completely unrelevant press releases that were sent to me and a bazillion other people.
speaker: Jason Feifer
context: Lenny asks Jason about the volume of pitches he receives from startup founders and PR people trying to get coverage. Jason is explaining the overwhelming amount of press pitches he receives daily as editor-in-chief of Entrepreneur Magazine. He emphasizes that most pitches are mass-distributed, irrelevant press releases rather than targeted, thoughtful outreach.
text_ko: 정말 어이가 없어요. 이 팟캐스트 녹음이 끝날 때쯤이면, 글쎄요… 제 받은 편지함(inbox)에 아마 30에서 50개 정도의 피치(pitches)가 들어와 있을 거예요. 하루 종일 계속 들어와요. 분명히 말하면, 그 중 대부분은 진짜 쓰레기예요, 말 그대로요. 완전히 관련 없는 보도자료(press releases)들이 저한테랑 수많은 다른 사람들에게 한꺼번에 발송된 거예요.
text_zh: 这太夸张了。我跟你说，等我们录完这期播客，我的邮箱里估计又得有，我也说不准，反正30到50个推销邮件(pitch)是跑不了的。这玩意儿一整天都在往里蹦。不过说实话，这里面大部分都是垃圾，真正的垃圾那种，对吧。基本上都是些跟我八竿子打不着的新闻稿，群发给我和其他一大堆人的。
text_es: Es una locura. Te diría que para cuando terminemos de grabar este podcast, voy a tener, no sé... Pueden ser entre 30 y 50 propuestas en mi bandeja de entrada. Me llegan todo el día. Ahora, para que quede claro, la mayoría de eso es pura basura, basura de la buena, ¿eh? Son un montón de comunicados de prensa que no tienen nada que ver conmigo y que me los mandaron a mí y a otros miles de personas.
key_sentence: Most pitches are garbage in the real garbagey sense, irrelevant press releases.

text: And that means that you could end up... I write this newsletter, right. I have... Entrepreneur Magazine is the thing that people obviously would pitch, but then I have this newsletter where I don't interview anybody. There's no opportunity to be featured in my newsletter, and I still get pitches to the newsletter because somebody saw it and dropped it in some spreadsheet, and it just... now I get it. And I think that's a real disservice to entrepreneurs who are paying for people to do that, and I really hate that.
speaker: Jason Feifer
context: Jason explains how automated PR systems work poorly for entrepreneurs. He describes how PR agencies often add publications to spreadsheets without understanding what they actually cover. Jason uses his own newsletter as an example - it doesn't feature interviews or stories about companies, yet he still receives irrelevant pitches because someone added it to a database without researching its format or purpose.
text_ko: 그 말은 결국… 제가 뉴스레터(newsletter)를 하나 쓰고 있다는 건데요. Entrepreneur Magazine 같은 곳은 당연히 피치(pitch)할 대상이 되겠지만, 제 뉴스레터는 사람 인터뷰를 하지 않아요. 제 뉴스레터에 소개될 기회 자체가 없는데도 누군가가 보고 스프레드시트(spreadsheet)에 넣어둔 탓에 계속 저한테까지 피치가 들어와요. 이제는 왜 그런지 알겠어요. 그런데 그게 PR이나 홍보업체에 비용을 지불하는 창업자들에게는 정말 불이익이라고 생각하고, 저는 그거 진짜 싫어요.
text_zh: 这就意味着你可能会遇到这种情况...我写这个newsletter(邮件通讯)，对吧。我有...《创业家》杂志是大家明显会想要推销的地方，但是我还有这个newsletter，我在里面不采访任何人。根本没有机会在我的newsletter里露脸，但我还是会收到各种推销邮件，就因为有人看到了，然后随手扔进某个Excel表格里，现在就...我明白了。我觉得这对那些花钱请人做推广的创业者来说真的是很坑，我特别讨厌这种做法。
text_es: Y eso significa que puedes terminar... yo escribo este newsletter, ¿no? Tengo... la revista Entrepreneur es obviamente lo que la gente querría que les publique, pero también tengo este newsletter donde no entrevisto a nadie. No hay manera de que te destaquen en mi newsletter, y aún así me siguen llegando propuestas para el newsletter porque alguien lo vio y lo metió en alguna hoja de cálculo, y ya... ahora me llega de todo. Y creo que eso es hacerles muy mal servicio a los emprendedores que están pagando por eso, y la verdad es que lo odio.
key_sentence: Pitches to my newsletter are a real disservice to entrepreneurs.

text: Think about press the same way that you think about raising money, which is to say you do it when you know what the money is for, and you should do it when you know what the press is for. A lot of people reach out to me at such an early stage that if we wrote about them, it wouldn't get them anything. They're not at a stage where they could use that press in any meaningful way, and so there's really no purpose in chasing it now.
speaker: Jason Feifer
context: Lenny asks Jason when it's worth investing time in getting press coverage. Jason draws a parallel between seeking press and fundraising, emphasizing that both should be pursued strategically when you have a clear purpose. He explains that many entrepreneurs seek press too early in their company's development, when coverage wouldn't actually benefit their business goals or stage.
text_ko: 언론(press)을 다루는 건 자금 조달(raising money)을 생각하는 방식과 똑같이 생각하세요. 돈을 모을 때 '이 돈이 뭘 위해 쓰일지' 분명할 때만 하는 것처럼, 언론을 활용할 때도 '언론이 어떤 도움이 될지' 알 때 해야 해요. 많은 분들이 너무 이른 단계에 저한테 연락을 주시는데, 그때 기사화가 된다 해도 실질적으로 얻는 게 별로 없어요. 지금은 언론 보도를 의미 있게 활용할 단계가 아니라서 굳이 쫓을 필요가 없어요.
text_zh: 做媒体报道就像融资一样，你得先想清楚钱拿来干什么用，同样的，你也得先想清楚媒体报道要达到什么目的。很多人太早就找到我，要是我们这时候报道他们，其实对他们一点好处都没有。他们现在这个阶段，根本用不上媒体曝光，所以现在去追求这些报道完全没意义。
text_es: Piensa en los medios de la misma manera que piensas en conseguir financiamiento: lo haces cuando sabes para qué vas a usar ese dinero, y con la prensa debería ser igual, hazlo cuando sepas para qué te va a servir esa cobertura. Un montón de gente me contacta en etapas súper tempranas, y si escribiéramos sobre ellos, no les serviría para nada. No están en un punto donde puedan aprovechar esa exposición de manera significativa, así que realmente no tiene sentido perseguirla ahorita.
key_sentence: Chasing it now has no purpose in a meaningful way.

text: But I get a lot of emails. It's funny because people are... like entrepreneurs, in particular, they're just so vulnerable, and it's kind of a wonderful way sometimes. And sometimes people will just email me, and they'll just say, "You know, I've worked really hard, and I just feel like I deserve this." I respect that, and I relate to it in some ways with my own trying to get attention for my own work. But, "I deserve this" that's not a good tactical decision for your business that doesn't do anything for you.
speaker: Jason Feifer
context: Jason continues explaining when it makes sense to pursue press coverage. He describes the emotional vulnerability of entrepreneurs who sometimes reach out saying they 'deserve' press coverage after working hard. While Jason empathizes with this feeling, he emphasizes that deserving coverage isn't a strategic business reason that will actually help achieve meaningful goals.
text_ko: 근데 저한테 이메일이 정말 많이 와요. 웃긴 건 사람들이, 특히 창업가들(entrepreneurs)은 되게 취약할 때가 많고, 그게 가끔은 오히려 참 좋은 방식이 되기도 해요. 가끔은 그냥 이메일로 "저 정말 열심히 일했으니까 이건 제가 받을 자격이 있어요"라고만 쓰기도 해요. 그런 마음은 존중하고, 저도 제 일을 알리려고 애썼던 경험이 있어서 어느 정도 공감해요. 하지만 "내가 받을 자격이 있어" 같은 생각은 사업에 있어서 좋은 전술적 결정(tactical decision)이 아니고, 실질적으로 별로 도움이 되지 않아요.
text_zh: 不过我收到很多邮件。有意思的是，创业者们特别容易流露真心，有时候这样挺好的。有时候有人会给我发邮件，就直接说："你知道吗，我真的很努力，我觉得我应该得到这个机会。"我能理解这种想法，我自己为了给作品争取关注度的时候也有过类似感受。但是，"我应该得到"这种想法对你的生意来说不是什么好策略，对你没什么帮助。
text_es: Pero recibo un montón de emails. Es curioso porque la gente... como los emprendedores, en particular, son muy vulnerables, y a veces es algo hermoso. Y a veces la gente me escribe y me dice, "Sabes qué, he trabajado muy duro, y siento que me lo merezco." Lo respeto, y en cierta forma me identifico con eso por mis propios intentos de llamar la atención sobre mi trabajo. Pero eso de "me lo merezco"... esa no es una buena decisión táctica para tu negocio, eso no te sirve de nada.
key_sentence: 'I deserve this' is not a good tactical decision for your business.

text: So that means that 99.5% of the people who would read a story about this guy have no ability to go get his hotdogs, which means that that was wasted effort. So fine. Was it that hard to come up and talk to me at the conference? No. But scale that out. How many emails is he sending that are like that? How much energy is he putting into chasing things that ultimately don't have good direct value to him?
speaker: Jason Feifer
context: Jason tells the story of a hot dog food truck owner in Washington DC who wanted coverage in Entrepreneur Magazine. Jason explains why this would be ineffective - Entrepreneur has a national/international audience, but the hot dog vendor can only serve local customers. Jason uses this example to illustrate how entrepreneurs often target the wrong publications that don't reach their actual customer base.
text_ko: 그러니까 이 얘기를 읽는 사람들 중 99.5%는 그 사람 핫도그를 사러 갈 수도 없는 사람들이란 뜻이에요. 그건 결국 노력 낭비였어요. 그럼 컨퍼런스에서 와서 나한테 그냥 말을 걸어보는 게 그렇게 어려웠을까요? 아니에요. 그런데 그걸 확장해 보면 (scale that out), 그런 식의 이메일을 그가 몇 통이나 보내고 있을까요? 결국 그에게 직접적인 가치(direct value)가 별로 없는 것들을 쫓느라 얼마나 많은 에너지를 쓰고 있는 걸까요?
text_zh: 这就是说，99.5%看到这个人故事的读者根本没法去买他的热狗，也就是说这些努力都白费了。好吧，在会议上过来跟我聊聊有那么难吗？没有。但你想想规模化的问题，他发了多少封这样的邮件？他把多少精力都浪费在追求那些对他来说根本没有直接价值的事情上？
text_es: Eso significa que el 99.5% de la gente que leería una historia sobre este tipo no puede ni siquiera ir a comprar sus hot dogs, o sea que fue esfuerzo perdido. Bueno, vale. ¿Era tan difícil acercarse a hablar conmigo en la conferencia? No. Pero ahora multiplica eso. ¿Cuántos emails estará mandando que son así? ¿Cuánta energía estará metiendo en perseguir cosas que al final no le van a dar buen retorno directo?
key_sentence: Scale that out; chasing things wastes direct value.

text: They don't care about you. They don't care about you. They care about their reader or their listener or their viewer. That's who they care about. That's who they're serving, and if you can be of use to them in sharing the kinds of information that they are looking to serve their audience, then you can get what you want. But you can't treat them like a service provider because they're not.
speaker: Jason Feifer
context: Jason explains a fundamental misunderstanding entrepreneurs have about media. Many people approach journalists and editors as if they're service providers whose job is to give coverage. Jason clarifies that media professionals' primary loyalty is to their audience, not to the people pitching them stories. He emphasizes that successful pitches must demonstrate value to the publication's readers rather than just promoting the entrepreneur's business.
text_ko: 그들은 당신에게 관심 없어요. 정말 관심 없어요. 그들이 신경 쓰는 건 독자나 청취자, 시청자예요. 바로 그 사람들이 그들이 돌보는 대상이고, 그들을 위해 일하는 사람들입니다. 만약 당신이 그들이 자기 청중에게 전달하려는 종류의 정보를 공유하는 데 도움이 될 수 있다면, 당신도 원하는 걸 얻을 수 있어요. 하지만 그들을 서비스 제공자(service provider)처럼 대하면 안 돼요. 그건 그들이 아니니까요.
text_zh: 他们根本不在乎你。真的，他们就是不在乎你。他们在乎的是他们的读者、听众或者观众。这些人才是他们真正关心的，他们就是为这些人服务的。如果你能帮到他们，提供他们想要分享给受众的那种信息，那你就能得到你想要的。但是你不能把他们当成服务商来对待，因为他们压根儿就不是。
text_es: No les importas tú. No les importas para nada. Les importa su lector, su oyente o su audiencia. Esa es la gente que les importa. A esos es a quienes están sirviendo, y si tú les puedes ser útil compartiendo el tipo de información que ellos buscan para servir a su audiencia, entonces puedes conseguir lo que quieres. Pero no los puedes tratar como si fueran un proveedor de servicios porque no lo son.
key_sentence: You must be of use to them, not treat them as a service provider.

text: So when people would pitch what we'd really be looking for are, are there insights into... in what this person is doing that other people could read and say, "Aha, that helps me understand where this industry is going or that industry, or it helps me think about how I can shape my own company to match current trends," that kind of stuff.
speaker: Jason Feifer
context: Jason explains the editorial mission differences between publications, using his experience at Fast Company as an example. When he worked at Fast Company under editor-in-chief Bob Safian, the magazine focused on where business was heading and evolution of industries. Jason describes what made stories appealing to Fast Company - they needed to provide insights that would help readers understand industry trends and adapt their own companies accordingly.
text_ko: 그래서 사람들이 피치를 할 때 우리가 실제로 보려는 건, 그 사람이 하는 일에서 다른 사람들이 읽고 “아, 이걸 보니까 이 업계가 어디로 가는지 알겠네, 아니면 우리 회사도 지금 흐름에 맞게 어떻게 바꿔야 할지 생각해 보게 되네”라고 말할 수 있는 인사이트(insights)가 있는지 보는 거예요.
text_zh: 所以当有人来提案的时候，我们真正想要的是——这个人做的事情能不能给别人一些启发，让别人看了会恍然大悟："哦，原来如此！这让我明白了这个行业的发展方向，或者那个行业的走势，或者让我知道怎么调整自己公司的策略来跟上当下的趋势。"就是这种东西。
text_es: Entonces cuando la gente nos venía con propuestas, lo que realmente buscábamos era si había insights... en lo que esta persona estaba haciendo que otros pudieran leer y decir "¡Ajá! Esto me ayuda a entender hacia dónde va esta industria o aquella, o me ayuda a pensar en cómo puedo adaptar mi propia empresa para seguir las tendencias actuales", ese tipo de cosas.
key_sentence: Insights that match current trends help others understand the industry better.
